instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3435: What is 820-3435? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U7090: What is U7090? This chip is often responsible for creating PP3V42_G3H.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWRGD: What is ALL_SYS_PWRGD? ALL_SYS_PWRGD is present when PP1V8_S3, PP5V_S3, PP1V2_S3, PP1V05_S0, PP5V_S0, PP3V3_S0, & PP1V5_S0 are present and working. If any of these rails is not working, ALL_SYS_PWRGD will be pulled down and the machine will not turn on. .
definitions.PPVRTC_G3H: What is PPVRTC_G3H? PPVRTC_G3H is a 3.3v power rail for the RTC circuit present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state. .
definitions.PP3V3_SUS: What is PP3V3_SUS? The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.PP5V_S4RS3: What is PP5V_S4RS3? PP5V_S4RS3 is a 5v power rail present when the machine is in an S4 suspend to disk state..
definitions.U1950: What is U1950? This chip often becomes corroded on pin 8 on the PP3V42_G3H pin causing PM_SLP_S4_L to go missing.
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> all rails are present. Not turning on.
threads.message:
Hi,

Got this 830-3435 borad with liquid damage at <CHIP>U7090</CHIP> area. No light on charger, not turning on. Replaced <CHIP>U7090</CHIP> and <CAPACITOR>C7090</CAPACITOR> repairing some lines between them. After that got PPBUS 8.06 that seems to be that my smc doesnt work. heat it with flux and now i am getting 8.61V. All other rails are present, machine charges battery but doesnt turn on.


What can i check next?

Thanks


P.S. all sys pwrg missing.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> all rails are present. Not turning on.
threads.message:
All rails are NOT present if <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> is missing.

What voltage do you currently have on PP3v42 and <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>? Light on the charger goes from green to orange and is steady? <SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> present? <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL>, and <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4RS3</SIGNAL> present?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> all rails are present. Not turning on.
threads.message:
Check if all big coils pulses too.
Any sign at VCORE?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> all rails are present. Not turning on.
threads.message:
[QUOTE="JohnB8812, post: 44330"] <SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> present? <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL>, and <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4RS3</SIGNAL> present? [/QUOTE]

All present except of <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4RS3</SIGNAL>. Not shorted to ground.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> all rails are present. Not turning on.
threads.message: So likely <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> is missing. There must?ve been liquid elsewhere besides <CHIP>U7090</CHIP>. Remove JTAG connector if you haven?t already. Inspect closely for corrosion near the SMC, BIOS and ALL probe points/resistors near it, <CHIP>U1900</CHIP> and its traces to Y1905, <CHIP>U1950</CHIP> and anywhere else in general.
